metadata.intent: Establish master bible for character 'ABE'
metadata.rationale: Consolidate character traits, evidence, and relationships from script.

master_v1.json.name: ABE
master_v1.json.description: Abe is a chronically tired, highly manicured 'silver fox' in his 50s. He is one of three senior interviewers/executives at BEL Inc., exuding an aura of commanding authority, refined elegance, and barely concealed volatility. He is impeccably dressed, stone-faced in professional settings, and operates with a practiced, almost theatrical control over every interaction. He possesses an uncanny ability to read people, which he leverages as both a professional and personal weapon. Beneath his polished exterior lies a man capable of sudden, explosive outbursts, crude humor, and psychological manipulation, yet also moments of surprising warmth and candor.

explicit_evidence.quote: Without breaking his eye-contact with Dante, Abe raises one 'enough' finger to Joaquin.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. BEL INC. OFFICE, WINTER, 1997 - JUST BEFORE DAWN

explicit_evidence.trait: Stone-faced and unreadable in professional settings
explicit_evidence.quote: Silence. The 3 interviewers are staring at her. Cassandra and Joaquin smile. Abe remains stone-faced.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. BEL INC. OFFICE, WINTER, 1997 - JUST BEFORE DAWN

explicit_evidence.quote: You either get rid of those shares now, or they will be as worthless as a used fucking condom.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. ABE'S OFFICE - MORNING

explicit_evidence.quote: Abe jumps up and runs to the corner of his office where we see a PUNCHING BAG. He intensely pounds off a few rounds.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. ABE'S OFFICE - MORNING

explicit_evidence.quote: I have a knack. I can read people. I used to think everybody could do it.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. GEMINI'S BAR VIP ROOM - LATER

explicit_evidence.quote: I AM RICH. I AM POWERFUL. AND NO ONE, AND I MEAN NO ONE, FUCKS WITH ME.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. GEMINI'S BAR VIP ROOM - LATER

explicit_evidence.quote: You have the rest of tonight to find out who our nutless Joe is. Without divulging our secret, of course. If you are correct in identifying this ball-less wonder, you can start your training.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. GEMINI'S BAR VIP ROOM - LATER

explicit_evidence.quote: Flickers through the swinging doors reveal Abe with the 'teacher' and 'high end hooker' from his psychic reading hours earlier. They're greeting him like old friends. Dante's laugh is bitter - she realizes she's been conned.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. GEMINI'S BAR VIP ROOM - LATER

explicit_evidence.trait: Refined elegance and grace under pressure
explicit_evidence.quote: The calmness that he exudes is in stark contrast to the frenzy of the crowd.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. 2ND LEVEL TRADING PIT - DANTE'S DESK

explicit_evidence.quote: No. No you don't. You're a woman. You have a little flower vagina. I have two giant balls. Two giant balls made of pure gold.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. GEMINI'S BAR VIP ROOM - LATER

inferred_traits.value: Abe takes Dante to lunch and invests significant personal time in her, but frames it as a test rather than genuine support, suggesting he cultivates talent for his own strategic purposes.
inferred_traits.rationale: He personally retrieves her heel and coat, takes her to lunch, shares personal stories, and sets up a challenge for her employment — all behaviors suggesting investment in her, yet the 'one nut' game and his deceptive 'psychic reading' reveal manipulation as the underlying motive.

inferred_traits.trait: Deep class consciousness and social Darwinism
inferred_traits.value: Abe believes power and wealth are earned through ruthlessness and cunning, and he judges others harshly by their social origins while simultaneously respecting those who claw their way up.
inferred_traits.rationale: His speech about 'two giant balls,' his dismissal of Dante's background as a 'Dominican sob story,' and his admiration for Cassandra's money-making ability all reflect a worldview where only the strong and cunning deserve success.

inferred_traits.value: Abe's theatrical outbursts, crude jokes, and dominance displays appear to be a carefully constructed armor over a more complex inner life hinted at by his childhood story.
inferred_traits.rationale: His story about being bullied in grade 7 and being small for his age reveals a formative vulnerability. His current persona of absolute dominance and control reads as a direct overcorrection from that early powerlessness.

inferred_traits.value: Abe treats nearly all relationships — with clients, employees, and new hires — as transactions to be managed and leveraged.
inferred_traits.rationale: He arranges a night out with a client to close a deal, instructs Laynah to 'look slutty' for a client visit, and frames Dante's employment as contingent on passing a game he invented — all pointing to a fundamentally transactional worldview.

inferred_traits.value: Abe processes environmental and personal details at an extraordinary level, using smell, sight, and behavioral cues to construct detailed profiles of people.
inferred_traits.rationale: He identifies Dante's soap brand, perfume, and the Saks tag on her jacket through smell and observation alone, and accurately profiles strangers at the bar — demonstrating a near-savant level of perceptual intelligence.

master_v1.json.dialogue_summary: Abe's dialogue is a masterclass in controlled dominance punctuated by sudden volatility. In the interview scene, he poses a morally ambiguous hit-and-run question with cold precision. In his office, he performs a high-pressure broker call with practiced theatricality, using a punching bag and fake frenzy to manipulate a client. At the bar, he oscillates between warm mentor and terrifying authority figure — sharing a genuine childhood story about his people-reading gift, then pivoting to explosive outbursts about power and wealth, crude anatomical humor, and finally a psychological game about identifying a one-testicled colleague. His speech patterns are characterized by deliberate pacing, rhetorical repetition for emphasis, and a tendency to interrupt others mid-sentence. He issues commands disguised as invitations and delivers rules as non-negotiable edicts.

relationships.evidence: Abe conducts Dante's interview, takes her to lunch on her first day, shares personal history, sets up a psychological employment test, and gives her a key chain — all while maintaining absolute power over her fate at BEL.
Abe credits Cassandra's influence ('the power of Cassandra's pussy') for Dante's interview opportunity and instructs Dante to emulate Cassandra as a money-maker.
Abe silences Joaquin with a single finger during the interview, suggesting seniority or at least equal standing with authority to override him.
Abe instructs Laynah to attend a client visit dressed 'slutty,' dismisses her concerns about hiring, and uses her as a personal errand runner — all with casual cruelty.
Abe performs an elaborate theatrical routine to keep Daniels calm and compliant, promising a night out and female companionship to close a deal.
Greta answers Abe's calls immediately and executes his instructions without question, suggesting a long-standing and efficient working relationship.

metadata.intent: Establish master bible for character 'ARMAN'
metadata.rationale: Consolidate character traits, evidence, and relationships from script.

master_v1.json.name: ARMAN
master_v1.json.description: Arman is a well-manicured Afghan male in his 40s who works as a cab driver. He speaks with a Farsi accent and carries himself with quiet dignity and genuine concern for others. Despite being treated dismissively and even rudely by his passenger, he remains composed, polite, and ultimately caring.

explicit_evidence.quote: The cabbie (ARMAN) is a well-manicured, AFGHAN MALE in his 40s.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: EXT. SIDEWALK IN FRONT OF TAXI

explicit_evidence.quote: (with a Farsi accent) Yes, sir.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: EXT. SIDEWALK IN FRONT OF TAXI

explicit_evidence.quote: No, Miss. Nobody paid me.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. CAB - 9PM - CONTINUOUS

explicit_evidence.quote: Where I come from, a man would never let a woman come home alone like this. Always, you should have a good man with you.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. CAB - 9PM - CONTINUOUS

explicit_evidence.quote: Can I ask, are you okay?
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. CAB - 9PM - CONTINUOUS

explicit_evidence.quote: Arman watches her with concern until she enters the building.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. CAB - 9PM - CONTINUOUS

inferred_traits.rationale: Arman remains calm and polite despite being spoken to dismissively, called derogatory nicknames, and accused of dishonesty by an intoxicated passenger. He never retaliates or loses composure.
He insists he was not paid even when Dante assumes he was, suggesting he would not accept money he did not earn, even if it would have been easy to do so.
His response of laughing and saying 'OKAY' when Dante accuses him of tricks suggests a light, non-confrontational sense of humor in the face of absurdity.

inferred_traits.trait: Traditional values regarding gender and protection
inferred_traits.rationale: His unsolicited comment about a man never letting a woman come home alone reflects deeply held cultural values around male responsibility and protection of women.
He attempts to open the door for Dante, watches her with concern until she is safely inside, and asks if she is okay — all unprompted acts of care toward a stranger who has been unkind to him.

scene_presence: EXT. SIDEWALK IN FRONT OF TAXI
INT. CAB - 9PM - CONTINUOUS
master_v1.json.dialogue_summary: Arman speaks sparingly but meaningfully. He begins with deferential compliance ('Yes, sir.'), then asserts his honesty when accused of double-charging ('No, Miss. Nobody paid me.'). He gently checks on Dante's wellbeing ('Can I ask, are you okay?') and offers an unsolicited cultural reflection on male responsibility toward women. His dialogue is calm, accented, and dignified throughout, contrasting sharply with Dante's slurred aggression.

relationships.relationship_type: cab driver to passenger / reluctant caretaker
relationships.evidence: Arman drives Dante home, endures her intoxicated hostility with patience, attempts to open her door, and watches her with concern until she enters her building safely.
Joaquin hails Arman's cab, hands him $100, and instructs him to take Dante home, treating him dismissively as a transactional figure.

master_v1.json.name: BROKER
master_v1.json.description: A generic broker working on the trading floor pit at Bel Inc. The character represents the collective crude, sexually charged, and rowdy culture of the brokerage floor. Two distinct lines are attributed to 'BROKER' as a label, suggesting either two different unnamed brokers or a composite voice of the pit crowd. Both lines are directed at Dante on her first day, showcasing the office's culture of sexual harassment masked as camaraderie.

explicit_evidence.quote: This is how we show our love around here, Dante!
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. BEL INC. CORRIDOR - RIGHT OF THE PIT (CONTINUOUS)

explicit_evidence.quote: Hey Dante! I would love to see a little more of your neckline...I mean, chest line. Fuck it. Your tits!
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. BEL INC. CORRIDOR - RIGHT OF THE PIT (CONTINUOUS)

inferred_traits.rationale: The BROKER lines are delivered in the context of a group eruption of crude behavior, each broker encouraging the next, suggesting the character embodies a mob-like group dynamic rather than individual agency.
Both lines involve sexual commentary directed at a new female employee on her first day, demonstrating a complete disregard for professional conduct.
The broker's behavior — including the air blowie pantomime and the chest-hair display — is performative and aimed at impressing peers as much as intimidating Dante.

After Dante throws her heel and hits the Clinton picture, the crowd (including the brokers) erupts in genuine approval and some give her nods, suggesting the brokers can shift their attitude when someone earns their respect on their terms.

scene_presence: INT. BEL INC. CORRIDOR - RIGHT OF THE PIT (CONTINUOUS)
master_v1.json.dialogue_summary: BROKER delivers two lines, both directed at Dante during her introduction to the trading floor. The first contextualizes the group's crude sexual pantomime as an expression of affection ('This is how we show our love around here, Dante!'). The second escalates to an explicit demand to see Dante's breasts. Both lines serve to establish the toxic, hyper-masculine culture of the brokerage floor rather than to develop an individual character.

relationships.evidence: BROKER directs sexually explicit and demeaning comments at Dante on her first day, representing the floor's hostile initiation culture.
Greta refers to the brokers as 'you boys' and laughs at their antics as though they are misbehaving children she indulges, suggesting a maternal authority relationship.
Both BROKER and MIKE THE SHIT participate in the same collective hazing of Dante, encouraging each other's behavior.
BROKER and MIKE CHRISTIAN participate together in the crude air blowie pantomime directed at Dante.

master_v1.json.name: CASSANDRA
master_v1.json.description: Cassandra Constantine is a late-30s woman described as well-put-together and stern, with a borderline English accent despite being born and raised in Manhattan. She is a senior power broker at BEL Inc., occupying a position of authority above the trading floor. She is impeccably presented, minimalistic in her workspace aesthetic, and operates with a commanding, no-nonsense demeanor that occasionally cracks to reveal warmth and even vulnerability. She is a self-appointed mentor to Dante, guiding her with blunt, sometimes brutal honesty, and is clearly a dominant force in the male-dominated office environment.

master_v1.json.dialogue_summary: Cassandra's dialogue is commanding, blunt, and often simultaneously directed at multiple people or situations (she frequently speaks while on the phone). In the interview scene she asks probing, direct questions. At the bar she delivers a brutal but motivating critique of Dante's appearance and a frank warning about the office's misogyny, framing herself as Dante's necessary ally. At Saks she issues terse directives to Liliane while conducting business calls. Her parting words to Dante outside Saks are cryptic and controlling ('don't ask, don't tell'). In the VIP room she arrives triumphant and celebratory, announcing she has secured the Cane account. Her speech patterns are clipped, declarative, and authoritative, with occasional moments of dry wit.

relationships.evidence: Cassandra vouches for Dante's hiring, takes her to breakfast, delivers a frank critique of her image, funds a complete makeover at Saks, and explicitly positions herself as Dante's protector and guide within BEL Inc.
Both are interviewers alongside Joaquin; Cassandra and Abe appear to share authority at the firm, with Abe's phone hanging up just before Cassandra's, suggesting coordinated communication.

Cassandra references Joaquin's ball gag joke with mild embarrassment ('Joaquin'), and Joaquin's humor is tolerated by her; she notes 'Joaquin will appreciate this one' regarding Dante's office outfit.
Cassandra repeatedly instructs staff to keep 'that JAP bitch' off her clients, and her crude references to Laynah suggest deep professional animosity.
Cassandra requests Greta set Dante up before the market opens, and interrupts Greta's tour to take Dante to breakfast, indicating she outranks or at least operates independently of Greta.
Liliane greets Cassandra by name, opens the store before hours for her, and refers to her as 'Ms. Constantine', indicating a long-standing, privileged client relationship.

metadata.intent: Establish master bible for character 'DANTE'
metadata.rationale: Consolidate character traits, evidence, and relationships from script.

master_v1.json.name: DANTE
master_v1.json.description: Dante De La Cruz is a mid-to-late 20s woman of mixed Haitian and Puerto Rican heritage with milk chocolate skin, dark hair, and big brown eyes. She is a newly hired broker-in-training at BEL Inc. in 1997 Manhattan, driven by a traumatic childhood marked by domestic violence and poverty. Fiercely ambitious, street-smart, and emotionally guarded, she is determined to achieve wealth and power so that no one can ever harm or control her again. She is simultaneously raw and resilient, navigating a brutal, chauvinistic financial world while concealing her vulnerabilities behind wit, bravado, and calculated self-control.

master_v1.json.dialogue_summary: Dante's dialogue moves between three registers: guarded ambition (her interview answers about wanting power and wealth), social navigation (attempting to charm or deflect the brokers, warming to Greta and Liliane), and raw vulnerability (her drunken confession to Abe about her family and past). She is often reactive rather than expository, revealing character through action and brief, pointed lines rather than monologue. Her most defining spoken moments are her interview declaration of wanting to be 'somebody nobody can fuck with,' her heel-throwing quip to the trading floor, and her whispered threat to Joaquin in the men's bathroom. Her phone call in the washroom early in the day reveals an unguarded, joyful side she otherwise suppresses. Her drunken cab ride home exposes exhaustion, self-doubt, and dark humor about her origins.

relationships.evidence: Cassandra vouches for Dante's hiring, takes her to Saks, funds her wardrobe, and explicitly tells her to 'do exactly what I say. Always.' Dante is simultaneously grateful and wary.
Abe tests Dante with the 'one nut' challenge, alternates between cruelty and warmth, and ultimately holds her employment fate. Dante defers to him while trying to read and impress him.
Joaquin sexually coerces Dante in the men's bathroom, threatening her job. Dante physically retaliates by grabbing his testicles and threatening him.
Greta immediately nurtures Dante, gives her Tylenol and band-aids, defends her implicitly, and offers unconditional support. Dante responds with genuine warmth.
Laynah shoots Dante a murderous glare on day one, refers to her as 'Dominican street trash,' and plants a soiled colleague at Dante's desk as a 'welcome present.'
Xander gives Dante water to balance her drinking, inadvertently provides the key clue about Dunaway's testicular cancer, and tells her to leave when Joaquin threatens her.
The opening scene of Dante's mother being beaten while Dante counts in Spanish establishes the foundational wound driving all of Dante's ambition and self-protective behavior.

relationships.relationship_type: Source of childhood trauma / Absent threat
relationships.evidence: The father is depicted as a large, frightening figure who strikes Dante's mother and silences Young Dante with a finger to his lips before walking out.

master_v1.json.dialogue_summary: Greta's dialogue is warm, instructional, and maternal. She guides Dante through the office with a sing-song narration of company culture, rules, and personalities. She introduces Dante to the brokers with playful affection, defuses tension with humor, and offers genuine emotional support. Her speech is peppered with diminutives ('Oopsies!', 'shall we?', 'love') and gentle authority. She also serves as a conduit for Abe's instructions, relaying reservation requests and office logistics without complaint. Her most revealing line — 'You will' (in response to Dante saying she doesn't smoke) — hints at a knowing, slightly fatalistic wisdom about the office's effect on people.

Greta rushes to Yuri with slacks and water, administers a pill, and physically helps him up despite him grabbing at her — all without complaint.

metadata.intent: Establish master bible for character 'XANDER'
metadata.rationale: Consolidate character traits, evidence, and relationships from script.

master_v1.json.name: XANDER
master_v1.json.description: Xander Lavery is a handsome, shy man in his 30s who works at Bel Inc. He is quietly observant and economical with his words, preferring minimal interaction but demonstrating a subtle, understated kindness and situational awareness. He occupies a position of some standing at the firm, evidenced by the shoe repair guy attending to him and his apparent familiarity with colleagues like Dunaway and Joaquin.

explicit_evidence.quote: Just what's necessary, please.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. BEL INC. CORRIDOR - RIGHT OF THE PIT (CONTINUOUS)

explicit_evidence.quote: Xander walks straight up beside her, sipping a CLEAR DRINK with a bobbing LIME. He says nothing to her, as they watch the drunk insanity in front of them, together.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. GEMINI'S BAR - 8:45PM - CONTINUOUS

explicit_evidence.quote: Here, water. You have to balance this.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. GEMINI'S BAR - 8:45PM - CONTINUOUS

explicit_evidence.quote: You know, ever since Dunaway had the testicular cancer, he's become a real pain in the ass health nut. He's even doing yoga.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. GEMINI'S BAR - 8:45PM - CONTINUOUS

explicit_evidence.trait: Decisive and protective in a low-key way
explicit_evidence.quote: Go.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. GEMINI'S BAR - 8:45PM - CONTINUOUS

inferred_traits.rationale: The script explicitly describes him as 'shy' and his behavior consistently reflects this — he approaches Dante without fanfare, speaks minimally, and does not draw attention to himself in either scene.

In the bar scene, Xander is the only person who assists Dante — offering her water, checking if she has eaten, and silently directing her to safety when Joaquin threatens her. This suggests a quiet protective instinct.

Xander is recognized by name by the shoe repair guy, has personal knowledge of Dunaway's medical history, and understands the social dynamics of the firm well enough to read Joaquin's volatile state and act accordingly.
His offhand remark about Dunaway's testicular cancer and yoga is delivered matter-of-factly, suggesting a dry wit rather than overt comedic intent.

While the brokers engage in crude, performative behavior toward Dante, Xander is conspicuously absent from that spectacle and instead offers quiet, practical support — suggesting he does not subscribe to the dominant macho culture of the floor.

scene_presence: INT. BEL INC. CORRIDOR - RIGHT OF THE PIT (CONTINUOUS)
INT. GEMINI'S BAR - 8:45PM - CONTINUOUS
master_v1.json.dialogue_summary: Xander speaks sparingly across both scenes. In the office corridor, he instructs the shoe repair guy with a single terse line. At the bar, he breaks the ice with Dante by sharing a dry anecdote about Dunaway's health transformation, offers her water and checks whether she has eaten, and then issues a single-word directive — 'Go.' — to protect her from Joaquin's wrath. His dialogue is consistently minimal, purposeful, and quietly considerate.

relationships.evidence: Xander is the only character who offers Dante practical help at the bar — water, concern about food, and a warning to leave — without any ulterior motive apparent in the text.
The shoe repair guy addresses him as 'Mr. Lavery' and attends to his shoes, mirroring the dynamic with Abe.
Xander references Dunaway's testicular cancer and lifestyle changes with familiarity, indicating a close enough working relationship to know personal details.
Xander reads Joaquin's volatile state immediately and directs Dante to comply with Joaquin's demand, suggesting awareness of and deference to Joaquin's authority.

metadata.intent: Establish master bible for character 'YOUNG DANTE'
metadata.rationale: Consolidate character traits, evidence, and relationships from script.

master_v1.json.name: YOUNG DANTE
master_v1.json.description: Young Dante is the childhood version of the protagonist Dante — a small girl with dark hair and big brown, frightened eyes. She is shown in a traumatic domestic violence scene in a dingy motel room, witnessing her mother being struck down by her father. Her frozen, trance-like state and quiet counting suggest a child coping with terror through a dissociative or self-soothing mechanism.

explicit_evidence.quote: We see YOUNG DANTE with dark hair and big brown, frightened eyes.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. DINGY MOTEL ROOM - LATE DAY

explicit_evidence.quote: Uno... Dos... Tres...
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. DINGY MOTEL ROOM - LATE DAY

explicit_evidence.quote: The little girl appears frozen in a trance as she looks down on her mother.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. DINGY MOTEL ROOM - LATE DAY

inferred_traits.rationale: The counting behavior, which morphs into adult Dante's internal voice, suggests a coping mechanism developed in childhood that persists into adulthood, implying a capacity to endure and survive extreme trauma.
Young Dante counts in Spanish ('Uno, Dos, Tres'), reflecting her Latina mother's cultural influence and the linguistic environment of her upbringing.

As a small child witnessing domestic violence — her mother bloodied on the floor and her large, intimidating father looming over her — she is entirely powerless and exposed to severe psychological harm.
When her father puts a finger to his lips, she does not cry out or react overtly, suggesting she has learned to suppress her responses in the presence of her threatening father.

scene_presence: INT. DINGY MOTEL ROOM - LATE DAY
master_v1.json.dialogue_summary: Young Dante speaks only a single line — counting in Spanish ('Uno... Dos... Tres...') — while frozen in shock watching her mother lying injured on the floor. This counting is a trauma response that bridges directly into adult Dante's internal voice, establishing it as a lifelong psychological coping mechanism.

relationships.evidence: Young Dante watches her mother get struck down and looks at her lying on the floor bleeding; their eyes meet in a moment of shared fear and attempted reassurance.
Dante's Father looms over Young Dante as a shadowy, threatening figure and silences her with a finger to his lips before walking out.
The little girl's counting voice morphs directly into adult Dante's voice (V.O.), establishing Young Dante as the childhood version of the protagonist.

master_v1.json.name: YURI
master_v1.json.description: Yuri is a 40-something man with salt-and-pepper hair, apparently of Russian origin, who works at or is associated with the brokerage firm. He is introduced in a disheveled and incapacitated state — face down at a desk with a wet pant leg — suggesting he had an accident (likely urinated on himself). Despite this, he is present at the VIP celebration later, where he is quiet, delayed in his reactions, and communicates minimally, primarily in Russian. He appears to have been instrumental in closing a significant deal ('Cane Deeds'), suggesting he holds a meaningful professional role despite his erratic personal state.

explicit_evidence.quote: Boobies...
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. 2ND LEVEL TRADING PIT - DANTE'S DESK

explicit_evidence.quote: We see YURI, (40-something man with salt-and-pepper hair), at the desk beside, face down, and one pant leg wet on the inside.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. 2ND LEVEL TRADING PIT - DANTE'S DESK

explicit_evidence.quote: Good!
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. PRIVATE VIP ROOM - DOORWAY

explicit_evidence.quote: WE GOT CANE DEEDS! That's right my friend, we did it!
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. PRIVATE VIP ROOM - DOORWAY

inferred_traits.rationale: Found face-down with a wet pant leg, requires a pill and water from Greta to be revived, and Joaquin jokes about his 'wet undies.' His delayed reactions and quiet demeanor at the VIP room further suggest ongoing intoxication or exhaustion from substance use.

inferred_traits.trait: Respected within the firm despite personal struggles
inferred_traits.rationale: Cassandra publicly credits him for closing the 'Cane Deeds' deal and celebrates him in front of the group, suggesting he is a productive and valued member of the team despite his personal state.
Yuri says almost nothing throughout both scenes, responds with thumbs up and delayed smiles, and allows Greta to handle him without resistance. He does not engage in the banter around him.

inferred_traits.value: Likely from overwork on the deal
inferred_traits.rationale: The script notes 'It looks like he has been up for days to help close this deal,' suggesting his disheveled state may be partly due to extreme work effort rather than purely substance abuse.

scene_presence: INT. 2ND LEVEL TRADING PIT - DANTE'S DESK
INT. PRIVATE VIP ROOM - DOORWAY
master_v1.json.dialogue_summary: Yuri speaks only twice, both times in Russian. In the first scene, he mumbles 'Boobies' while grabbing at Greta's breasts as she helps him up. In the second scene, he responds 'Good!' with a thumbs up when Joaquin mocks him. His communication is minimal, delayed, and non-English, making him largely a visual and comedic presence rather than a verbal one.

Cassandra publicly credits Yuri for closing the 'Cane Deeds' deal and celebrates him in front of the group.
Joaquin mocks Yuri with nicknames like 'Yurine,' 'Yee,' and 'Pee,' and jokes about his wet undies, though without apparent malice.

master_v1.json.name: Motorola Cellphone
master_v1.json.description: A brand-new, oversized 1997-era Motorola brick-style cellular phone. Large and unwieldy by modern standards, it is given to Dante by Greta as part of her onboarding at BEL Inc. on her first day. The phone is a symbol of Dante's entry into the world of wealth and professional status. Joaquin is also seen wielding two giant Motorola cell phones simultaneously, one to each ear, underscoring the device as a status symbol of power and connectivity among the firm's elite. Cassandra also uses a cell phone throughout the day to manage clients and broker deals.
scene_presence: INT. BEL INC. EMPTY WASHROOM - EARLY MORNING: Dante excitedly calls someone on her brand-new giant Motorola to announce she got the job, holding it awkwardly and brimming with joy.

INT. 3RD FLOOR CORRIDOR - MORNING: Dante retrieves the Motorola from her cheap purse to show Cassandra when asked if she received her office phone; Cassandra instructs her to have it on her at all times.
INT. PRIVATE VIP ROOM - DOORWAY: Joaquin enters the bar's VIP room with one giant Motorola cell phone to each ear and one on his chest, conducting multiple loud conversations simultaneously.
master_v1.json.narrative_significance: The Motorola cellphone functions as a layered symbol throughout the pilot. For Dante, it represents her first tangible acquisition of professional status and upward mobility — she calls a loved one on it with pure elation, marking the threshold between her impoverished past and her aspirational future. Cassandra's instruction to keep it on her at all times signals Dante's entry into a world of constant availability and control. For Joaquin, the dual giant Motorolas are an extension of his outsized personality and power, visually communicating his dominance and the firm's culture of excess. The prop grounds the story firmly in 1997 and serves as a recurring emblem of the wealth, connectivity, and status that define BEL Inc.

data.script_text:
LIBERTY AND CHURCH (ALTERNATE TITLE: OVERJOY)

"PILOT - INTO THE FIRE"

INSPIRED BY REAL PEOPLE, REAL EVENTS

TEASER

A BLACK SCREEN-

Sounds of a man and woman arguing in Puerto Rican Spanish are peppered with those of tumbling furniture and shattering glass.

FADE IN:


INT. DINGY MOTEL ROOM - LATE DAY

A SMALL FIGURE quickly scampers to a CHAIR in a corner of the room. We continue to hear yelling and things being thrown around the room.

The light from the setting sun is coming through the MOTEL room WINDOW and hits the face of the small figure. We see YOUNG DANTE with dark hair and big brown, frightened eyes.

SMACK--

The little girl sees DANTE'S MOTHER (30s, Latina, fragile yet tough) head hit the floor in front of her. Her mother is lying on her side with her eyes wide open and looking up at the little girl. A trickle of blood starts trailing down her jawline from her ear. Her eyes are scared yet attempting reassurance.

The little girl appears frozen in a trance as she looks down on her mother.

YOUNG DANTE
Uno... Dos... Tres...

The sun illuminates behind DANTE'S FATHER (30s, Haitian, large and scary) as his shadowy figure looks up to the little girl. He puts a finger to his lips and walks out.

CUT TO BLACK

--we hear the little girl's voice morph into the voice of a woman counting in a whisper in her head.

DANTE (V.O., CONT'D)
... Quatro... Cinco... Seis...

FADE IN:


INT. BEL INC. OFFICE, WINTER, 1997 - JUST BEFORE DAWN

We see a man's lower jaw and mouth moving while talking.
The counting appears to be for the man's teeth.

DANTE (V.O., CONT'D)
... Siete... Ocho... Nueve...

We are looking at the patterns of a woman's dress.
Then, to a woman's mouth moving. No sound, until...

CASSANDRA
... Dante?

CASSANDRA (late-30s woman, well-put together and stern). She has a borderline English accent, but she was born and raised here, in Manhattan.

DANTE (V.O.)
Yes. Ummm...

JOAQUIN
You havin' a seizure? You wanna borrow Cassandra's ball gag so you don't swallow your tongue?

JOAQUIN is a chubby, short, half-bald with a burnt hair comb-over male in his 50s). His mother is a Newfoundlander, and he often uses the accent when cracking jokes, which is most of the time.

A third set of eyes is looking at the woman. This is ABE, a chronically tired, highly manicured 'silver fox' in his 50s.

They are all affluently dressed and in 3 expensive leather office chairs.

Across from these 3 figures is DANTE (mid-late 20s stunning woman with milk chocolate skin).

The room is slightly dark in these last moments before dawn. There is nothing else in the room but a window and a FIERY PAINTING worth more than most people's homes, behind the interviewers.

Without breaking his eye-contact with Dante, Abe raises one 'enough' finger to Joaquin.

ABE
I will repeat the question this once. If you ran over someone on your way to work, would you stop, or would you keep going?

DANTE
I would keep going.

JOAQUIN
You got human fucking blood all over your grill. You keep going?

DANTE
No. I would stop first. I would see how they are.

Dante's eyes dart frantically to all the interviewers.

ABE
And if stopping would cause you to miss the market opening in London...?

JOAQUIN
You just whammed someone, and you're shitfaced. You think it's wise to stop?

DANTE
Well, no, not if I was going to be late. I would keep going if I was going to be late...
(beat; confused)
I'm on my way to work?

JOAQUIN
Exactly.

Joaquin sits back. All is quiet and all 3 are staring at Dante.

MIKE THE SHIT
I'm not going to cheers with her until she tells us what Abe said.
(he intensifies his stare)
What was that secret all about? Hey, Dante?

Dante freezes for a moment.

MIKE CHRISTIAN
Yah, good point Mike.
(turns to Dante)
No secrets in this firm. Not wise to get off to a bad start with us. We're your allies.
(beat)
Management will just use you to get what they want. We are the ones who support each other. And since Abe isn't exactly an open book, we need to know any grain of information that he may divulge. Now, 'fess up.

They are all nodding. Yuri nods with a delay.

Dante sits back and nonchalantly looks at Mike Christian's crotch beside her. We see a bit of a bulge, but it is hard to tell in suit pants. She is feigning that she is thinking and rubbing the back of her neck.

MIKE THE SHIT
Were you just staring at Mike's crotch?

MIKE CHRISTIAN
No secrets between us, right?
(beat)
9 inches.

They all burst out laughing. Dante immediately tries to change the subject.

DANTE
Sooo, how long you guys been at the firm?

MIKE THE SHIT
Don't try and change the subject. How about we play a little drinking game, winner gets the secret? A little, 'who here owns... ?' game?

Nods all around. Everyone reaches for a shot.

MIKE THE SHIT
Who here owns a Porsche?

No one drinks.

DUNAWAY
If you don't, you have to drink.

DANTE
Ok, wait, wait. This isn't fair. I just started here...

MIKE THE SHIT
It's the rules. We all play by the rules. Don't we guys?

They are all nodding. Dante tips back her shot.

MIKE THE SHIT
Next question. Who here owns a mansion in The Hamptons.
(to Dante)
Do you? Drink up.

The guys are laughing and drinking their champagne. As Dante reaches for a shot -


INT. PRIVATE VIP ROOM - DOORWAY

BAM! The deep brown leather, brass-trimmed, saloon-style doors to the room fly open. Joaquin enters quickly, 1 GIANT MOTOROLA CELL PHONE in each hand, one to his ear, one on his chest. He has a cigar hanging out of his mouth, plumes of smoke billowing upwards.

JOAQUIN
(into phone, very loud)
...you want what? Hold on... I'm on an important call.

He puts that phone to his chest and takes the other one to his ear.

JOAQUIN (CONT'D)
(into phone)
Ok. 3 pairs of Valentino custom made. Have 'em here by next week. And don't you dare send me that ass hide you tried selling me last week. Alright... bye-bye.

He hangs that phone up and takes the one on his chest up to his ear.

JOAQUIN (CONT'D)
Tamara... honey. What's wrong with your Maserati? Don't you have homework? Go make yourself a stiff drink until the craving passes.

He hangs up and loudly bangs both phones on the bar like setting his rifles down at the end of the day.

JOAQUIN (CONT'D)
Chewie!

We can see that Kensington loves his humor and equally loves to sass him back.

JOAQUIN (CONT'D)
(pointing to the TVs above the bar playing the news)
Turn that shit up!

KENSINGTON
(while grabbing the remote)
Fuck you, Joaquin.

Joaquin looks towards the booth, impressed that she just said 'fuck you' to him.

We see the brokers in the booth laughing.

He extends his arms to their furthest length on the bar wood while still looking at the booth.

JOAQUIN
I want this many shots! Make them from the House of Cognac..

Joaquin is still looking at the booth, especially Dante, eyes twinkling.

Kensington starts setting up SHOT GLASSES between his hands. His hands don't move.

Everyone at the booth leans back, laughing.

DUNAWAY
Herrrrrre comes The Joaquin Show. Brace yourself Dante.

The group is laughing and nodding as they all nurse a shot.

JOAQUIN
Hey... HEY! Make 'em tight as your arse, Blanche.

Dante watches as Kensington fills every square inch of space between his outstretched arms with shooters. We also notice that she is pouring from the LOUIS XIII CRYSTAL BOTTLE, $10,000/bottle.

Mike Christian nods his head towards Mike the Shit.

MIKE CHRISTIAN
Just be happy Mike's not ordering the shots.

Mike the Shit gives him a long-armed punch from across the table. To Dante:

MIKE CHRISTIAN (CONT'D)
See what I mean?

Joaquin lumbers over with 2 shots in each hand, fingers in the shot glasses and giant phones under his armpits. The humor in his walk is only exacerbated by the bulky pager and beeper hanging off his belt loops.

In the b.g. Kensington is loading the rest of the shots; a double-decker tray.

JOAQUIN
Holy shit, what a motley crew! Make some room for some high quality.

He seems to be referring to himself and his shooters as he pushes his way into the sardine booth, facing the TVs. He passes Dante the two shots in his right hand. While licking the booze off his fat finger and thumb:

JOAQUIN (CONT'D)
(to Dante)
OHHHHHHH STATE! You look a fright!
(looks at her again)
So, how's it goin', Fancypants?

He looks over at Yuri, who has been quiet up to this point. Joaquin flamboyantly jumps back in feigned fright.

JOAQUIN (CONT'D)
Jesus! You got a face on you like a bag 'o smashed assholes! What's the matter YURINE, wet undies givin' you a rash?

Yuri smiles with a delay and gives a thumbs up.

YURI
(in Russian)
Good!

Everyone is laughing. This man has a joke a second, not that you can understand them.

JOAQUIN
Holy shit. We better git some medicine in ya.

Kensington arrives and places all the shots Joaquin just bought on the adjacent two-top.

KENSINGTON
Startin' out slow, are we?

Joaquin is beckoning to Kensington to bring him a couple of shots from his stash.

JOAQUIN
(pointing at Kensington and then Yuri)
Get me one for Yee, and one for Pee.

The group snickers. Joaquin hands it to Yuri and looks to Dante and Kensington for a cheers.

JOAQUIN (CONT'D)
Down the hatch.

Joaquin gives a little look to the group, and they all grab a shot from the table. The group shoots them back. Yuri, with a delay, shoots his back also.

JOAQUIN (CONT'D)
Holy shit, if I wanted to have tea with the queen, I woulda went to Buckingham fucking palace. Come on, miss, let's go.

He pushes her second shot towards her brashly. She has a mini dry heave when she takes the shot and the group snickers. They all join her for a second shot. Joaquin just grabs a random from the table.

JOAQUIN (CONT'D)
(makes a face)
Gasoline!

Joaquin is rubbing the chest hair spewing out of his opened dress shirt top, tie in his breast pocket. He seems to be studying her while continuing to rub his chest hair.

JOAQUIN (CONT'D)
So, who made you? Two mutts?

Dante has no idea what he is talking about, and it shows.

MIKE CHRISTIAN
He means, who are your parents?

Joaquin loves when someone understands what he is saying. With a wink and a head jerk, to Mike C.:

JOAQUIN
Spot on, buddy.

MIKE CHRISTIAN
Don't worry, he doesn't always talk like this. His Newfie always comes out when he drinks... or when it's showtime.

JOAQUIN
It's NEWFOUNDLANDER to you, my son...

The group laughs. Joaquin looks back at Dante, awaiting her response.

DANTE
My mom is Haitian, and my dad is Puerto... wait, no... other way around... ?

Dante is laughing. She is too drunk to remember her parents' heritage. Joaquin is shaking his head again.

JOAQUIN
Holy shit, she's not gonna last a minute. Maybe you need a shot of PENIS-CILLIN?

He grabs his package (he likes to do this). The group is killing themselves laughing. Dante eyes seem to linger a bit too long on him grabbing his package as she attempts a quick testicle count.

JOAQUIN (CONT'D)
Ahhh, you like that? Well, there is a lot more where that came from.

The group is still laughing. He drops his package and looks at the group as though he didn't just do anything raunchy.

JOAQUIN (CONT'D)
So, what's the word boys?

MIKE THE SHIT
Well, Dante here has a secret that Abe told her. She won't divulge.

JOAQUIN
No secrets here, Dante. Rule #1.

Laynah walks up beside Joaquin. She has changed her shirt so that her fake boobs are bursting out the impossibly small bodice she's stretched over them. She has clearly re-done her make-up, hair, and outfit. She is smiling through her fire engine red lipstick -- which is all over her front teeth.

LAYNAH
What's going on, boys?

As we see Dante take a sigh of relief, Joaquin turns his head right into her cleavage.

JOAQUIN
Holy shit! Ma? Ma? Is that you, MA?

He is nose deep into her cleavage and is grabbing at her breasts, as though trying to recognize them. She slaps his hands away.

LAYNAH
Screw you, Joaquin. Move over.

She barely fits herself at the end of the booth.

Dante looks to her and rubs her front teeth as though to tell her there is lipstick on her teeth -- girl code, and as an olive branch. She needs someone on her side here.

Laynah, as usual, doesn't understand, and pretends to rub her front teeth right back, as though mocking Dante's actions. Although, she doesn't quite touch her teeth, so they stay stained.

Joaquin leans over to Dante and whispers. Well, ok, he speaks loud enough for everyone to hear.

JOAQUIN
Stunned as mi arse.

Laynah hits Joaquin. He laughs.

Cassandra walks through the saloon doors, just hanging up her phone. This seems to be a much looser Cassandra than Dante from earlier as she is, yes, dancing her way towards the bar. She is quite drunk.

She stops short of the bar and throws her arms up.

CASSANDRA
This night's on MEEEEE! WE GOT CANE DEEDS!

She is pointing towards Yuri.

CASSANDRA (CONT'D)
That's right my friend, we did it!

Yuri smiles and gives another thumbs up. It looks like he has been up for days to help close this deal. We see the guys around him congratulating him.

CASSANDRA (CONT'D)
Your best tequila all around, Kensy!
(beat, pointing to the TVs)
Turn that shit down, and the music UP!

We see Kensington turning down the TVs and turning up the stereo. We notice that she has turned on the TV subtitles.

The group starts clapping and whooping.

JOAQUIN
(leaning into Dante)
Don't think we are done with you.

He puts his hand on her leg and holds it there a bit too long.

As Cassandra dances over, we see everyone reaching for a shot for cheers.

The music is loud, and the party has officially started. CLINK!

INT. GEMINI'S PRIVATE VIP ROOM - LATER

There is loud club music (something like Gypsy Kings - Bamboleo) and flashes of VERY DRUNK QUICK CLIPS between black transitions. We hear some dialogue here and there. Things like, 'you wanna see the real thing?' when she is caught looking at someone's package. 'What's the secret?' 'What did Abe tell you?' 'DANTE! WHAT IS THE FUCKING SECRET?!'

Here we also see Paul and SMITH who is the co-owner of the bar, and twin brother of Kensington. He is in his early 30s, handsome (almost pretty), and sweet looking. Kensington introduces him to Dante. Dunaway and Smith are laughing together.

Cassandra is on the bar table singing, Dante and others are dancing, shooters are being tipped back, there is lots of drinking, lots of drugs, blow off hookers, gambling at the tables, men reaching for their giant money wads, brokers making out with women, Laynah giving a blowjob to a broker in a booth, and some have their arms around each other and are singing loudly. We really see the brotherhood, men demeaning women, and the excessiveness in this scene.

Everyone, including Dante, seems to be having the time of their life.

We also see scenes of Cassandra telling her to 'straighten up/hold yourself together' while snorting coke from her giant, SILVER RING.

END OF ACT THREE

ACT FOUR


INT. PRIVATE VIP ROOM - LATER

Dante looks quite green. She is swaying and her eyes look like they are blinking independently of each other. She is sweating and her make-up is running down her face.

Joaquin notices her state, grabs her, and quickly ushers her into the men's washroom.


INT. GEMINIS - MEN'S WASHROOM

As they enter, we see PAUL, in front of the urinal,
just zipping up his pants under his giant gut. He
looks from Joaquin to Dante to Joaquin's 'get the fuck
out of here' face.

He exits very quickly without a word.

SHUNNNNNNNNNNNP. Joaquin drags the GARBAGE CAN in
front of the door.

He reaches into his pocket and takes out a rather
LARGE BAG of WHITE POWDER and a STRAW. He proceeds to
create a line on the side of the sink with his one of
his BLACK VISA CREDIT CARDS (we see him choosing).

JOAQUIN
You need to straighten up.
(passing her the straw)
Here.

Dante has never done drugs in her life. Drinking,
yes. Drugs, no.

She is drunk. She is disinhibited. She grabs the straw
and shakily places it at the start of the line. We hear a
big SNIIIIIFFFFFFFF as the white powder slowly
disappears.

As Dante's head comes up, we see that she has a fair
amount under her nose, and she is choking.

DANTE
It musta went down the wrong tube--

Joaquin face reflects his disdain, and he hands
her his pocket napkin.

JOAQUIN
-- Jesus. Wipe that shit up

NEWBIE BEFORE SOMEONE LICKS
it from yer nose. This is

SOME VELVETY SHIT. DON'T
waste it.

He takes a small, what looks like a BRASS LOCKET, out
of his other pocket. There is a small, BRASS STRAW on
top. He takes a different baggie of white powder out
of the other pocket and makes a fat line.

As his head comes up, we see his face and eyes are
blazing red. He is a whole different, and scarier,
person than earlier.

JOAQUIN (CONT'D)

ENOUGH'S ENOUGH. I'M GIVING
you 3 choices: you either
tell me Abe's secret, I fire
you... or (beat) you blow me.
Right now, Spic.

Dante wildly stares at Joaquin.

After a long beat, she walks towards him slowly,
seductively. As she approaches, she lays her hand on
his giant gut. He looks at her, sweating like a pig.
Her hand slowly trails down his King Henry VIII mound,
towards his groin. She undoes his zipper. Her hand
slips in. He is smiling and his head tilts back.

She grabs his testicles hard. So much so that we see
his body slightly raise on the wall. He is wincing in
pain. All men watching the show should be saying,
Mama, along with him.

DANTE
(whispering into his ear)
Do you want to keep both of
these, or shall I bring one
to Abe, as bounty, and create
my own destiny?

Joaquin is shaking his head yes, then no, then...
whatever he is trying to convey, it clearly means, LET
GO. She lets go of his testicles and we see him
slightly drop to the floor. Lower than before as he
is hunching in pain and somewhat winded.

JOAQUIN
(breathlessly)
Bitch.

Dante exits the washroom.


INT. GEMINI'S BAR - 8:45PM - CONTINUOUS

Dante is coming out of the bathroom, sweating.

Xander walks straight up beside her, sipping a CLEAR DRINK with a bobbing LIME. He says nothing to her, as they watch the drunk insanity in front of them, together.

Dante looks to him and sees that he is watching Dunaway tuck into a SALAD. Her eyes follow to Dunaway eating.

XANDER
You know, ever since Dunaway had the testicular cancer, he's become a real pain in the ass health nut.
(beat)
He's even doing yoga.

Xander hands her his drink.

XANDER (CONT'D)
Here, water. You have to balance this.

Dante gratefully takes the water and downs it.

XANDER (CONT'D)
Have you even eaten today?

Before she can respond, Joaquin storms out of the washroom, red faced, sweaty, and freshly coked up. He is walking a bit funny.

DANTE
(to self)
Uh-oh...

JOAQUIN
(enraged and shouting)
I think it's time that our new little piggy takes herself alllllll the way home.

Joaquin is at the bar exit pointing at Dante and motioning her towards the door. He is adjusting himself in his pants.

The crowd that is close enough to hear starts laughing and oinking, before going back to their shenanigans. Dante looks around and no one seems to be helping her except Xander, who cocks his head towards the door.

XANDER
Go.

Dante exits quickly.


EXT. SIDEWALK IN FRONT OF TAXI

Joaquin is behind Dante, marching her out. He immediately waves a CAB down and opens a door for her.

JOAQUIN
Get in.

As Dante heads towards the cab, we see that walking has suddenly become very difficult. He grabs her arm and roughly sits her in the cab, closes the door and walks around to the CABBIE'S window. He pulls his THICK MONEY CLIP out, full of HUNDREDS.

JOAQUIN (CONT'D)
Take this ditch pig home.

The cabbie (ARMAN) is a well-manicured, AFGHAN MALE in his 40s. Joaquin slips the cabbie $100.

ARMAN
(with a Farsi accent)
Yes, sir.

Arman starts asking Dante where to go, we see Joaquin moving back around the cab with a strange smile slowly curling across his face.

He pats the back of the cab a couple of times to send it off.

BAM! BAM!


INT. CAB - 9PM - CONTINUOUS

Fade in from black. It is quiet. Only the motor of the cab is heard.

We see Dante wilting in the back, head in hands.

DANTE
(to self)
Fuck. Fuck. Fucka. Fucka. Fucka. Fuck.

Dante slumps against the cab window, eyes glassy. The city streaks past - grey apartments, neon liquor signs, faceless corner stores - smearing together like wet paint. All she wants is to disappear.

Arman stops in front of her building.

ARMAN
That will be $20.

Dante takes a minute to look at him in the rear-view mirror. She is blinking slowly and speaking in slurs.

DANTE

NICE TRY.
(peering at his tag on the dash)
What's your name?

ARMAN
My name is Arman, Miss.

DANTE
Is this fucking joke, Ar-mee?

ARMAN
Sorry?

DANTE
I get your opportunity eye, but you been paid.

ARMAN
No, Miss. Nobody paid me.

Dante takes a moment, looking at him.

DANTE
THIS ISN'T FUCKING PAKISTAN, AR-MEE.
(beat)
I know these tricks. Don't fuck with me.

ARMAN
(laughing)

OKAY.
(beat)
Can I ask, are you okay?

DANTE
No. I'm not fucking okay. I'm fucked.

ARMAN
Miss, can I say?

DANTE
Am I home now?

ARMAN
Where I come from, a man would never let a woman come home alone like this. Always, you should have a good man with you.

DANTE
(laughing)
R-man... where I come from, this is what a good man does.

He gets out to open her door.

DANTE
NO! I'll do it.

Arman just shakes his head as she smiles and flips him a slow bird.

She exits the cab on her own (with great difficulty) and heads to the front door of a brownstone building with her middle finger still extended. Her heels are in her hand again and her legs seem to be working less and less.

Arman watches her with concern until she enters the building.


INT. APARTMENT BUILDING, CORRIDOR IN FRONT OF APT. DOOR. - JUST PAST 9PM

Dante is in front of an apartment door rustling for her keys in her purse. She pulls the keys back and looks at all of them. She notices a new KEY CHAIN. It is two, golden testicles with a mini plaque saying 'He Who Owns the Gold Rules'. She has a brief memory of Abe giving her these telling her she 'needs a pair'.

Dante looks up to take the moment in and smiles.

When she finally finds her key, she keeps trying the lock and missing while longer transition scenes of black are occurring.

When she finally gets the key part of the way in, it doesn't seem to fit.

FADE TO BLACK.

We hear a 'bang' and a 'thump' in the dark...

FADE IN:

Dante is lying on her side with her eyes wide open. One eye is quickly swelling. She is looking upward. A trickle of blood starts trailing down her lips from her nose.

FADE TO BLACK.

metadata.intent: Establish master definition for character 'ABE'
metadata.rationale: Extracted from canonical script and scene co-occurrence data.

data.description: Abe is a chronically tired, highly manicured 'silver fox' in his 50s. He is one of three senior interviewers/executives at BEL Inc., exuding an aura of commanding authority, refined elegance, and barely concealed volatility. He is impeccably dressed, stone-faced in professional settings, and operates with a practiced, almost theatrical control over every interaction. He possesses an uncanny ability to read people, which he leverages as both a professional and personal weapon. Beneath his polished exterior lies a man capable of sudden, explosive outbursts, crude humor, and psychological manipulation, yet also moments of surprising warmth and candor.
data.dialogue_summary: Abe's dialogue is a masterclass in controlled dominance punctuated by sudden volatility. In the interview scene, he poses a morally ambiguous hit-and-run question with cold precision. In his office, he performs a high-pressure broker call with practiced theatricality, using a punching bag and fake frenzy to manipulate a client. At the bar, he oscillates between warm mentor and terrifying authority figure — sharing a genuine childhood story about his people-reading gift, then pivoting to explosive outbursts about power and wealth, crude anatomical humor, and finally a psychological game about identifying a one-testicled colleague. His speech patterns are characterized by deliberate pacing, rhetorical repetition for emphasis, and a tendency to interrupt others mid-sentence. He issues commands disguised as invitations and delivers rules as non-negotiable edicts.

inferred_traits.rationale: He personally retrieves her heel and coat, takes her to lunch, shares personal stories, and sets up a challenge for her employment — all behaviors suggesting investment in her, yet the 'one nut' game and his deceptive 'psychic reading' reveal manipulation as the underlying motive.
inferred_traits.value: Abe takes Dante to lunch and invests significant personal time in her, but frames it as a test rather than genuine support, suggesting he cultivates talent for his own strategic purposes.

inferred_traits.rationale: His speech about 'two giant balls,' his dismissal of Dante's background as a 'Dominican sob story,' and his admiration for Cassandra's money-making ability all reflect a worldview where only the strong and cunning deserve success.
inferred_traits.trait: Deep class consciousness and social Darwinism
inferred_traits.value: Abe believes power and wealth are earned through ruthlessness and cunning, and he judges others harshly by their social origins while simultaneously respecting those who claw their way up.

inferred_traits.rationale: His story about being bullied in grade 7 and being small for his age reveals a formative vulnerability. His current persona of absolute dominance and control reads as a direct overcorrection from that early powerlessness.
inferred_traits.value: Abe's theatrical outbursts, crude jokes, and dominance displays appear to be a carefully constructed armor over a more complex inner life hinted at by his childhood story.

inferred_traits.rationale: He arranges a night out with a client to close a deal, instructs Laynah to 'look slutty' for a client visit, and frames Dante's employment as contingent on passing a game he invented — all pointing to a fundamentally transactional worldview.
inferred_traits.value: Abe treats nearly all relationships — with clients, employees, and new hires — as transactions to be managed and leveraged.

inferred_traits.rationale: He identifies Dante's soap brand, perfume, and the Saks tag on her jacket through smell and observation alone, and accurately profiles strangers at the bar — demonstrating a near-savant level of perceptual intelligence.
inferred_traits.value: Abe processes environmental and personal details at an extraordinary level, using smell, sight, and behavioral cues to construct detailed profiles of people.

data.name: ABE

relationships.evidence: Abe conducts Dante's interview, takes her to lunch on her first day, shares personal history, sets up a psychological employment test, and gives her a key chain — all while maintaining absolute power over her fate at BEL.
Abe credits Cassandra's influence ('the power of Cassandra's pussy') for Dante's interview opportunity and instructs Dante to emulate Cassandra as a money-maker.
Abe silences Joaquin with a single finger during the interview, suggesting seniority or at least equal standing with authority to override him.
Abe instructs Laynah to attend a client visit dressed 'slutty,' dismisses her concerns about hiring, and uses her as a personal errand runner — all with casual cruelty.
Abe performs an elaborate theatrical routine to keep Daniels calm and compliant, promising a night out and female companionship to close a deal.
Greta answers Abe's calls immediately and executes his instructions without question, suggesting a long-standing and efficient working relationship.

metadata.intent: Establish master definition for character 'ARMAN'
metadata.rationale: Extracted from canonical script and scene co-occurrence data.

data.description: Arman is a well-manicured Afghan male in his 40s who works as a cab driver. He speaks with a Farsi accent and carries himself with quiet dignity and genuine concern for others. Despite being treated dismissively and even rudely by his passenger, he remains composed, polite, and ultimately caring.
data.dialogue_summary: Arman speaks sparingly but meaningfully. He begins with deferential compliance ('Yes, sir.'), then asserts his honesty when accused of double-charging ('No, Miss. Nobody paid me.'). He gently checks on Dante's wellbeing ('Can I ask, are you okay?') and offers an unsolicited cultural reflection on male responsibility toward women. His dialogue is calm, accented, and dignified throughout, contrasting sharply with Dante's slurred aggression.

He insists he was not paid even when Dante assumes he was, suggesting he would not accept money he did not earn, even if it would have been easy to do so.
His response of laughing and saying 'OKAY' when Dante accuses him of tricks suggests a light, non-confrontational sense of humor in the face of absurdity.
His unsolicited comment about a man never letting a woman come home alone reflects deeply held cultural values around male responsibility and protection of women.

metadata.intent: Establish master definition for character 'CASSANDRA'
metadata.rationale: Extracted from canonical script and scene co-occurrence data.

data.description: Cassandra Constantine is a late-30s woman described as well-put-together and stern, with a borderline English accent despite being born and raised in Manhattan. She is a senior power broker at BEL Inc., occupying a position of authority above the trading floor. She is impeccably presented, minimalistic in her workspace aesthetic, and operates with a commanding, no-nonsense demeanor that occasionally cracks to reveal warmth and even vulnerability. She is a self-appointed mentor to Dante, guiding her with blunt, sometimes brutal honesty, and is clearly a dominant force in the male-dominated office environment.
data.dialogue_summary: Cassandra's dialogue is commanding, blunt, and often simultaneously directed at multiple people or situations (she frequently speaks while on the phone). In the interview scene she asks probing, direct questions. At the bar she delivers a brutal but motivating critique of Dante's appearance and a frank warning about the office's misogyny, framing herself as Dante's necessary ally. At Saks she issues terse directives to Liliane while conducting business calls. Her parting words to Dante outside Saks are cryptic and controlling ('don't ask, don't tell'). In the VIP room she arrives triumphant and celebratory, announcing she has secured the Cane account. Her speech patterns are clipped, declarative, and authoritative, with occasional moments of dry wit.

metadata.intent: Establish master definition for character 'DANTE'
metadata.rationale: Extracted from canonical script and scene co-occurrence data.

data.description: Dante De La Cruz is a mid-to-late 20s woman of mixed Haitian and Puerto Rican heritage with milk chocolate skin, dark hair, and big brown eyes. She is a newly hired broker-in-training at BEL Inc. in 1997 Manhattan, driven by a traumatic childhood marked by domestic violence and poverty. Fiercely ambitious, street-smart, and emotionally guarded, she is determined to achieve wealth and power so that no one can ever harm or control her again. She is simultaneously raw and resilient, navigating a brutal, chauvinistic financial world while concealing her vulnerabilities behind wit, bravado, and calculated self-control.
data.dialogue_summary: Dante's dialogue moves between three registers: guarded ambition (her interview answers about wanting power and wealth), social navigation (attempting to charm or deflect the brokers, warming to Greta and Liliane), and raw vulnerability (her drunken confession to Abe about her family and past). She is often reactive rather than expository, revealing character through action and brief, pointed lines rather than monologue. Her most defining spoken moments are her interview declaration of wanting to be 'somebody nobody can fuck with,' her heel-throwing quip to the trading floor, and her whispered threat to Joaquin in the men's bathroom. Her phone call in the washroom early in the day reveals an unguarded, joyful side she otherwise suppresses. Her drunken cab ride home exposes exhaustion, self-doubt, and dark humor about her origins.

explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. BEL INC. OFFICE, WINTER, 1997 - JUST BEFORE DAWN

inferred_traits.trait: Distrust of authority figures, especially men

data.name: DANTE

relationships.evidence: Cassandra vouches for Dante's hiring, takes her to Saks, funds her wardrobe, and explicitly tells her to 'do exactly what I say. Always.' Dante is simultaneously grateful and wary.
Abe tests Dante with the 'one nut' challenge, alternates between cruelty and warmth, and ultimately holds her employment fate. Dante defers to him while trying to read and impress him.
Joaquin sexually coerces Dante in the men's bathroom, threatening her job. Dante physically retaliates by grabbing his testicles and threatening him.
Greta immediately nurtures Dante, gives her Tylenol and band-aids, defends her implicitly, and offers unconditional support. Dante responds with genuine warmth.
Laynah shoots Dante a murderous glare on day one, refers to her as 'Dominican street trash,' and plants a soiled colleague at Dante's desk as a 'welcome present.'
Xander gives Dante water to balance her drinking, inadvertently provides the key clue about Dunaway's testicular cancer, and tells her to leave when Joaquin threatens her.
The opening scene of Dante's mother being beaten while Dante counts in Spanish establishes the foundational wound driving all of Dante's ambition and self-protective behavior.
The father is depicted as a large, frightening figure who strikes Dante's mother and silences Young Dante with a finger to his lips before walking out.
relationships.relationship_type: Source of childhood trauma / Absent threat

metadata.intent: Establish master definition for character 'GRETA'
metadata.rationale: Extracted from canonical script and scene co-occurrence data.

data.description: Greta, known affectionately as 'Greatness' by the brokers, is a woman in her 40s who serves as the office manager of Bel Inc. — though she functions more as an office mother. She possesses a wholesome beauty, a perma-smile, and a sing-song voice. Her desk area is decorated in yellow and feels like a country home. She is the emotional and logistical backbone of the office, nurturing new employees, managing chaos with grace, and maintaining warm relationships with even the most unruly brokers.
data.dialogue_summary: Greta's dialogue is warm, instructional, and maternal. She guides Dante through the office with a sing-song narration of company culture, rules, and personalities. She introduces Dante to the brokers with playful affection, defuses tension with humor, and offers genuine emotional support. Her speech is peppered with diminutives ('Oopsies!', 'shall we?', 'love') and gentle authority. She also serves as a conduit for Abe's instructions, relaying reservation requests and office logistics without complaint. Her most revealing line — 'You will' (in response to Dante saying she doesn't smoke) — hints at a knowing, slightly fatalistic wisdom about the office's effect on people.

He is boisterous, crude, sexually inappropriate, and relentlessly humorous in social settings, but reveals a darker, more threatening and volatile side when under the influence of cocaine.
data.dialogue_summary: Joaquin's dialogue is relentlessly loud, crude, and joke-driven, frequently deploying his Newfoundland accent for comedic effect. He uses vulgar nicknames, sexual innuendo, and physical humor to dominate social situations. In professional settings he is terse and pointed. His most revealing dialogue occurs in the washroom, where cocaine strips away his comedic persona and exposes a coercive, racist, and sexually threatening man who attempts to leverage Dante's vulnerability for personal gain. After being physically subdued by Dante, he resorts to calling her a 'bitch' and then publicly ejects her from the bar.

She is territorial, status-conscious, and openly hostile toward newcomers she perceives as threats, particularly Dante. She operates within the firm's boys-club culture, performing femininity and compliance when it serves her (e.g., entertaining clients) while wielding social cruelty as a power tool against other women.

She opens by privately branding Dante 'Dominican street trash,' then challenges Abe's hiring decision using misogynistic language she has absorbed from the firm's culture. In the corridor she feigns warmth while immediately pivoting to steal credit for Daniels' account. On the trading floor she frames a humiliating 'welcome gift' (a disheveled Yuri) as a joke at Dante's expense. In the VIP room she inserts herself into the group, deflects Joaquin's groping with mild irritation, and fails to register Dante's genuine attempt at female solidarity.

The scene establishes the chaotic, intense, and sometimes crude culture of the trading floor, introduces key supporting characters in her immediate vicinity, and demonstrates the power dynamics with Abe's watchful presence. The desk becomes the staging ground for Dante's transformation from outsider to insider, marking her physical claim to a space in this male-dominated, high-pressure environment.

metadata.intent: Establish master definition for location 'Abe'S Office'
metadata.rationale: Extracted from canonical script and scene headings.

data.description: A stunning, pristine, and regal office space that reflects the wealth and power of its occupant. The office features a sprawling, elegant desk covered with neatly stacked documents and newspapers, with a pager and beeper positioned at the corner. A giant painting of a storming ocean dominates the wall behind the desk. The room includes a small leather love seat at the back, a punching bag in one corner, and a stereo system. The space is immaculately maintained and exudes an atmosphere of high-stakes finance and masculine dominance.
data.name: Abe's Office
data.narrative_significance: Abe's office serves as the command center and throne room for the protagonist, establishing his character as a high-powered, manipulative broker. The space physically manifests his personality through its contradictions: regal elegance paired with a punching bag, organized professionalism alongside aggressive tactics. The office is where Abe orchestrates his manipulative phone tactics with clients like Steven Daniels, demonstrating his practiced deception (fake urgency, stereo tricks). It's also a space where power dynamics play out with employees like Laynah, who must wait on the love seat while Abe conducts business. The brief glimpse of Dante and the blonde woman through the doorway hints at broader office dynamics and Abe's awareness of his surroundings even while focused on deals.

The space represents the hierarchical structure of the company (executive elevator, Joaquin's surveillance office, Greta's elevated position) while simultaneously showcasing the unruly, circus-like atmosphere of the trading floor. The corridor is a liminal space between management oversight and broker chaos, where company policies (mandatory Thursday shoe buffing) meet workplace harassment, and where Dante transforms from a flustered newcomer clinging to Greta's arm to a confident barefoot woman who earns the brokers' respect.

data.description: An upscale, exclusive bar frequented by financial brokers before official opening hours. The interior features deep mahogany wood and plush red leather booths, creating an atmosphere of old-money sophistication. The establishment operates with drawn window shades and low lighting during these early morning sessions, maintaining privacy for its clientele. Multiple television screens mounted throughout display various news channels at low volume, while French techno music plays in the background. The bar has a wood counter where the lone early-morning bartender serves what are euphemistically called 'breakfast juices' - orange-tinted drinks that are essentially pure alcohol.
data.name: Gemini's Bar
data.narrative_significance: Gemini's Bar serves as a private, exclusive space where the power dynamics of the financial world are reinforced and mentorship relationships are established outside the formal office environment. It's where Cassandra takes Dante for a brutal but transformative conversation about survival in the male-dominated trading world. The bar represents a liminal space between the public professional world and private dealings - operating before hours for select clientele who receive special treatment. The setting facilitates Cassandra's harsh makeover advice and establishment of dominance over Dante through the ritual of drinking 'breakfast juices.' The bar's exclusivity and the bartender Emma's complicity (doing whatever brokers tell her, helping them exit quickly) underscore the privileged access and informal networks that define success in this world. This location marks a crucial turning point where Dante begins her transformation under Cassandra's mentorship.

data.description: An upscale luxury department store in New York City, representing wealth, status, and transformation. The location serves as a private shopping venue where exclusive clients receive personalized service before regular business hours. The store features elegant interiors with controlled lighting, elevator access, and private shopping areas where complete makeovers take place.
data.name: Sak's Fifth Ave
data.narrative_significance: Sak's Fifth Ave functions as a transformational threshold location where Dante undergoes a 'Pretty Woman'-style makeover that symbolizes her entry into the high-powered, morally ambiguous world of finance. The private, after-hours shopping experience emphasizes the exclusivity and privilege of Cassandra's world, while the transformation from Dante's original clothing (which she chooses to have burned) to provocative high-end attire represents her shedding of her former identity. The location establishes class dynamics, the transactional nature of appearances in this world, and foreshadows Dante's corruption. Liliane's gracious service and personal business card suggest Dante's acceptance into an elite circle, while the 'Pretty Woman' reference deliberately evokes themes of commodification and reinvention.

issues.description: Duration confidence (0.85) is misaligned with the actual uncertainty. The canonical title states '1 Hour Pilot' but the scene index estimates 28 minutes. The output resolves this to 60 minutes, yet assigns high confidence (0.85) despite this fundamental contradiction between two authoritative sources. Confidence should be lower (0.55-0.65) given this ambiguity.

Location count of 18 appears understated. The scene index lists 28 unique locations explicitly. The output's rationale mentions only 18 and acknowledges 'variations of the same location,' but this conflates distinct locations (e.g., 'Gemini's Bar - 1Pm' vs 'Gemini's Bar - 8:35Am' are separate scene headings). The count should be 28 or justified more rigorously.

Target audience assigned null with confidence 0.7, justified by 'no specific target demographic stated.' However, the rationale itself identifies the audience as '18+ adults interested in prestige drama.' This is a stated inference, not an absence of information. Either assign a value ('Adults 18+') or lower confidence to 0.5 to reflect the contradiction.

Genre classification as 'Financial Thriller' is plausible but not explicitly supported by the script text. The script is clearly a drama with crime elements, but 'thriller' implies suspense/mystery as primary drivers. The script is more character-driven drama with criminal elements. Consider 'Drama' and 'Crime' as primary genres.

Primary characters list excludes 'YOUNG DANTE' and 'DANTE'S FATHER/MOTHER' who appear in the opening teaser. While Dante is the protagonist, the opening scene establishes her traumatic backstory through these characters. Their omission is defensible but worth noting.

metadata.intent: Establish master definition for prop 'Motorola Cellphone'
metadata.rationale: AI-identified significant object from canonical script.

data.description: A brand-new, oversized 1997-era Motorola brick-style cellular phone. Large and unwieldy by modern standards, it is given to Dante by Greta as part of her onboarding at BEL Inc. on her first day. The phone is a symbol of Dante's entry into the world of wealth and professional status. Joaquin is also seen wielding two giant Motorola cell phones simultaneously, one to each ear, underscoring the device as a status symbol of power and connectivity among the firm's elite. Cassandra also uses a cell phone throughout the day to manage clients and broker deals.
data.name: Motorola Cellphone
data.narrative_significance: The Motorola cellphone functions as a layered symbol throughout the pilot. For Dante, it represents her first tangible acquisition of professional status and upward mobility — she calls a loved one on it with pure elation, marking the threshold between her impoverished past and her aspirational future. Cassandra's instruction to keep it on her at all times signals Dante's entry into a world of constant availability and control. For Joaquin, the dual giant Motorolas are an extension of his outsized personality and power, visually communicating his dominance and the firm's culture of excess. The prop grounds the story firmly in 1997 and serves as a recurring emblem of the wealth, connectivity, and status that define BEL Inc.
scene_presence: INT. BEL INC. EMPTY WASHROOM - EARLY MORNING: Dante excitedly calls someone on her brand-new giant Motorola to announce she got the job, holding it awkwardly and brimming with joy.

INT. 3RD FLOOR CORRIDOR - MORNING: Dante retrieves the Motorola from her cheap purse to show Cassandra when asked if she received her office phone; Cassandra instructs her to have it on her at all times.
INT. PRIVATE VIP ROOM - DOORWAY: Joaquin enters the bar's VIP room with one giant Motorola cell phone to each ear and one on his chest, conducting multiple loud conversations simultaneously.
